subject: Test EJB 2.0 entity Beans with JUnit and ServerTestCase extension
msgSnippet: Hi, I was able to test Entity bean local interface (CMP) in EJB 2.0 with Junit interface. This does not require web, jsp or servlet as most of the framework
messageBody:
Hi,
I was able to test Entity bean local interface (CMP) in EJB 2.0
with Junit interface.

This does not require web, jsp or servlet as most of the
framework proposed. Hence no war file etc.

This can be down easily with ServerTestCase framwork extension,
even the original ServerTestCase extension post did not indicate this
can be down.

Testing regular java class with Junit is easy; Testing EJB
session can be down easily as well. But testing EJB entity bean with
local interface is not as easy, simply because there is no remote
interface to be invoked.

There are several approaches to test EJB local interfaces:

1. Write an session bean as EJB entity bean's proxy and test
against the session bean proxy. This approach is not good, as every
change in entity bean interfaces, one has to change session bean as
well as test cases.

2. Another one is to dyanmically invoked the test cases inside the
server.

The ServerTestCase extension using an EJB session bean to allow
test cases be involked inside the application container, through the
this particular session Bean. This fit perfectly for the second
approach.

I tried it out and it works for me.

The only things need to watch out are:

1. Test case needs extends ServerTestCase not TestCase
2. Test case are intended to be called inside server, so
Context ctx = new InitialContext() should have no arguments
3. TestCase needs to be deployed to application server
4. According EJB 2.0 spec (correct me if i miss understand it)
The session bean should declare ejb-ref or ejb-local-ref
for all the EJB entity beans used.

This is going to be a drag if we constant need to change
deployment descriptor for the ServerTestCase's session bean when we
add new entity beans. But the good news is some application server
such as Weblogic 6.1 SP2 does not seem to reply on this to find the
ejb beans. So One can uses one type of application server to test and
develop.

I am using weblogic 6.1, and I did not declare ejb-ref or ejb-
local-ref. It works fine for me.


Hope this helpful for someone out there.


Chester
